message: So  مُحَمَّد أبو آدم, we know you don't like mongoDB and why, what do you usually use instead?

data.message: MongoDB is very useful, why don't you like it ? مُحَمَّد أبو آدم
Another alternative: Postgres. A relational DB, but has datatypes for array, hash & json

Let me drop my bomb, I have done my own storage solution for mobile. (It has some problems)

My Solution vs SQLite
insertion faster 72 times , retrieval 100 times.

The fun part it has no query language just callback to filter what you want in 2 modes (sequential and binary with comparator)

It supports in memory query (it loads all files in the memory and query form it)
it uses multi indexes (non clustered index) for all the rows except for string based

It uses string dictionary to minimize the size of the string fields, in short I store array of indexes pointing to the string in a dictionary (it is fast enough that you will not feel that this string is being constructed on the fly)
I hate DBs :D, but I like the semantic part in Postgres and dynamics of MongoDB
http://thenextweb.com/dd/2014/03/27/facebook-google-linkedin-twitter-launch-webscalesql-custom-version-mysql-massive-databases/
What about RavenDB?

MongoDB has a lot of serious problems in performance. unless you are a big company who is willing to pay 5000 dollars to ask for 1 hour consulting from the Mongo Team don't use it. 

This article explains most of the issues MongoDB has: http://www.computing.co.uk/ctg/news/2330148/viber-explains-why-it-ditched-mongodb-and-redis-in-favour-of-couchbase
So, Alaa, what do you use often? Another document thingy?  MySQL or some clone? Postgres or some other relational thingy? No DBs? etc.
مُحَمَّد أبو آدم The article says that Mongo is good when your inserts are 10K/s, which I think is enough for a lot of people.
I would recommend Couchbase it's much much lighter and scale better with many application servers http://www.couchbase.com/viber

Mohammad Tayseer no one know when he will need to scale his architect to that big scale like viber. but if you plan correctly from the start I believe this will save you a lot in the future. also we had a lot of issues with mongoDB below 10K/s .

Kngine used to use MongoDB as far as I remember and they forked it so they make it fit for their needs and I think they have done cool stuff with it, unfortunately they didn't share any of what they have done with it.
مالو ال access
Ahmed Essam Naiem this is a question out of this subject. but do you know if Siri has some sort of an API to convert audio to text? or any alternative? doesn't need to mobile based :)

There is some open source libraries for Speech recognition + Siri engine it self is open for use (I think you just need to put their logo on your product)
This is Dragon SDK for Windows.
http://www.nuance.com/for-developers/dragon/client-sdk/index.htm

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_speech_recognition_software

Also I never tried to play with Google "Undocumented" Speech Recognition APIs (It is something used with Google voice Input for Android and Google Now in Chrome browsers)
By far Google is the best :D, it supports ton of languages and it is more reliable, though it require some hacking.
Yes i tried it but they are still sucks in Spanish and even English :S
Mohamed Meligy are you searching for the best NoSQL eninge or you just search for the alternatives? Personally I find RavenDB is good and I'll start using it so soon in one of my projects
Can't believe no one mentioned Redis
RavenDB is slow http://mono.servicestack.net/mythz_blog/?p=474
Redis work best as a caching layer ;)
Disagree :D with two persistent modes that is very clever I don't see why not using it as a data store. Combined with twemproxy its far better than anything mentioned here.
it depends on your use case. but fore sure you will know what i mean if you manage millions of entries a day and when your server gives you the middle finger you will know what i mean :D
